However, I have paid attention to the speeds from 0% on up, and the HTC 10 does 0-30% in 35 minutes. Though that is what HTC claimed, I was looking forward to Qualcomm Quick Charge 3.0 and Qualcomm's claim of 0-80% in 35 minutes. So to me, it just defeated the whole purpose. @richii0207

Qualcomm never said that the 10 charged that fast, or any phone in particular for that matter. As you can imagine, a phone with 3000mah charges significantly faster than a phone with 5000 mah and a phone that is streaming while charging will charge slower than an idle phone. As Qualcomm and HTCs word for the 10, it charges up to 50% in just 30 minutes.

I'd write a long reviews but when I hit submit, the lovely xda forum say that need to be logged to submit a reviews, and reset the form. I love you random programmer guy! 

Anyway, long story short, I love my htc, I resisted a lot of drops, and is working like the first day. I just miss the sony flashtool from my z2, being able to install updates without wipe (since my phones are rooted and android 6 wont install updates on modified system partition's phones).

I won't be going back to Samsung any time soon.  For me the 10 is the perfect size and the build quality is excellent. I paid cash up front for a US unlocked directly from HTC US. It came with no bloatware and was easy to root and install a custom rom. Best phone I have ever had.

I ran custom roms on Samsung devices for years, but there always seemed to be something that didn't work. I would get a phone call and the screen would go black, or WiFi would keep dropping, it was always something. I haven't had any of those problems with the 10 on Sense-based custom roms.

threads.text:
Having had my HTC 10 since it was released (so well over a year), I'm still really pleased with it. 

Main likes:
- Build quality is excellent and feels solid
- The camera is the best of any smartphone I've had (not that I've owned a Galaxy S8 or an iPhone 7, but I've taken some great pictures with it)
- Wired sound quality is superb. Shame it doesn't cover bluetooth as well, though.
- Fingerprint reader is very snappy
- Sense is pretty stock Android-ish if you use a different launcher, pixel dialer and stock lockscreen, which I prefer
- Battery life is generally pretty good, and fast charge works well
- Expandable storage
- Nice strong vibration. I can't stand phones with a soggy feeling vibration :P
- Some great ROMs!

A few downsides:
- Phone speaker definitely not as good as the One M8, but it's fine
- Some updates wouldn't go amiss, HTC, seriously. January security patch? It's now July.
- Touchpal can do one

Felt inspired to write this as a crack has recently appeared in the screen (it has had a few drops so not surprising) and I've been thinking about either getting it repaired or replacing with a new phone. Considered a U11 (too expensive), Oneplus 5 (doubt the camera is better than the 10) and the LG G6 (amazing screen and camera, shoddy battery life allegedly), but not sure I'm ready to give the 10 up just yet!

My wife's grandmother watered mine and the capacitive buttons stopped working. 
It's the second smartphone that gets ruined by water. I hate glass back smartphones but having Waterproof is making me think a little different. 

Enviado do meu HTC One_M8 através de Tapatalk

I've been a huge fan of HTC since the original HTC One and have owned basically ALL their flagship phones (including the ill-fated M9+ and the upper midranger One A9).
In between those times, I have been switching through other brands (Moto X and Z and even Huawei). Heck, I even sold my grey HTC 10 just after a month!

Just last month, I stumbled through Lazada Malaysia and got surprised that they were selling the HTC 10 (unlocked) for USD300!!! (crazy Raya month sale). The Galaxy S8 was around USD530 (sale already ended). To cut this short, I bought my second HTC 10 (silver this time around)

I still have my other phone (Huawei P10) and will definitely sell this due to the crappy UI. 

Anyway, here's my ranking of my favorite HTC flagship:
HTC One (M7) - 10/10 -- this is THE perfect 10! fast camera, great in lowlight, wide angle rear AND selfie camera, boomsound. I think this phone was 3 years ahead of its time so reviewers don't get why HTC decided to put these features.

HTC 10 - 9/10 -- everything you want on a phone is here. My only gripe is the boomsound. I can't feel the **oomph** you hear on the M7 and M8. Also, IP67 could have been a nice addition (so potential consumers won't complain it doesn't have one!)

HTC One M8 - 9/10 -- the dual camera (which again, HTC was ahead of the time AND reviewers were scratching their heads coz of this "gimmicky" bokeh images) But since Apple says it's an important feature, reviewers are going ga-ga over the bokeh now. Sheesh.
-- Boomsound! gahhh!!! Nobody can beat the awesome boomsound! The bass is punchy, the speakers are very loud. Just wow!

HTC One A9 -- 7/10 --yes, I bought this phone since it looks like an iPhone. There's this side of me who wants to try an iPhone just for the sake of having one and good thing HTC built this. LOL. Camera is just good at best. The ultrapixel selfie camera is great. Speaker is average (no boomsound here). The battery went from OK to MEH after the nougat update.

HTC One M9+ -- 7/10 -- so much disappointment mainly because of the main camera. Not sure what HTC was thinking in putting a toshiba sensor on their phone. My first phone to have a fingerprint sensor and yes, the fingerprint recognition is faster the the iPhone 6 and Galaxy S6 (same year it was released).

I didn't mention anything about the sound quality when plugged in through the headset jack. It's because ALL of them are really GREAT. I'd say the closest competitor is Moto. They also deliver great audio quality with above average loudness.

I've been a fan of this phone ever since it got announced, by that time, i'm still on my previous Samsung N4 (and eventually N5). Long story short, i made the leap and went ahead to purchase the 10 around March this year and never regret the decision I've made. (except a bit disappointed with no other option for colors except gold....meh) 

Of course, due to the nature of my work in construction, the note series always have been the perfect companion in everyday task, but again i decided to hell with  that and give the 10 a try. 

Pros
+ amazing built quality, it survived leaving a dent at top edge after falling from waist level without a case (obviously!)
+ responsive and quick with everyday task you throw at it, and i game a lot with this phone
+ much less bloatware
+ great stereo speaker setup, compared to my previous phones I've used
+ perfect size, even after snapping a clear case by spigen, the phone is still easy to operate in one hand

Cons
- when it gets hot, it really does until to the point you snap back the case as it gets uncomfortable to hold when gaming
- camera is no where better than my N5, which is a bit disappointing 

After 3 months using the device, i put on the bamboo skin by dbrand to cover the less appealing gold color, matching with the white front of the phone, absolutely gorgeous. My device is still performing rock solid, and I don't think I'll change anytime soon, even after the U11 announcement. I don't know why I kept hesitating to make the jump again to U11, maybe because I am not a fan of all glass back. 

That's pretty much me sharing my thoughts to everyone, thanks for reading!

I am a fan of HTC smartphones since my One M7. HTC makes really good phones with a good quality construction.

What's your take on this?  HTC 10 vs LG G6?

replies.text:
The two phones are incredible. I have an HTC 10 and my friend a G6. We have compared both phones in terms of quality and performance. 

Really like the G6 display with HDR support. But nothing so far from the HTC 10 screen, except the 18:9 aspect ratio and a higher brightness level.

Sound in the G6 is louder, but sharper on the 10. Very good sound quality in both cases.

The build quality is what you can expect in a flagship, but I like more the aluminium of the 10 than the glass of the G6, it feels more resistant.

The G6's camera app is more complete than the 10 one, but photo quality is nearly the same on both devices. But when the G6's wide angle comes to play, it's simply fabulous. 

So, you will hit whatever device you choose, it's more a personal preference. Both are great phones and they aren't to far in terms of hardware.

replies.text:
I still have my M8 along with my current 10.  Both are S-Off, rooted, etc and running their respective version of ViperRom.  10 is a lot faster...though I do miss my IR blaster...lol...which is a main reason I keep it (I'll also use it as my GPS/music device in my car mount hotspotted to my 10.

Faster not only in look and feel but in benchmarks...and although its an outdated benchmark...quadrant scores on my M8 are always in the 28-32000 range.  10 is always in the 43-46,000 range. I find that simple benchmark usually correlates to how I feel my phone is running at the time.

Interesting note though....Xposed KILLS my 10's performance (quadrant scores drop to anywhere between 18,000 when "sluggish" to only 30,000 when it seems to be running okay but slower than without it).  to where I had to uninstall it.  It has no effect on my M8 in performance.
So in everyday real world use you notice the speed difference? I ask this because the M8 on Marshmallow is so smooth already, I don't get how it can get even faster.

It definitely scrolls, transitions, initializes/runs more programs faster, etc.  better camera.  Headphone sound is better...debatable if the phone speakers are...I did love the M8 boom sound and until MM had the harmon kardon mod on it.

I upgrade every year as work pays for it and we get the subsidized price ($199)...so I can't say whether it's worth the $600 plunge to upgrade from the M8 to 10...at this point you could probably stay happy with the M8 and wait to see what HTC cooks up in March/April with their next flagship.  Worst case scenario you'll get the 10 on a huge discount with the new flagship out.

Before sleep. 
Turn off ambient display. 
Switch off wifi
Switch off location. 
Switch off NFC 
Kill all apps. 
Avoid apps that are intrusive,  ie: push notifications constantly,  and take over the notification bar.  Ads etc  
Lower the amount of accounts you have syncing.  
Avoid mail apps that do what your native email app can do. 
Eg: yahoo mail vs mail app.
Switch off double tap to wake and all other gestures. 
Switch off ok Google. 
Switch off Google location service. 

If rooted. 
---------

Other than that there isn't a great deal more you can do.

Here is my "light" usage: 2h45m SOT, 54hrs off the charger, 52% used. All the use is over 4G LTE (good 3 bars), no wifi (see my post about wifi drain at: http://forum.xda-developers.com/htc-...ng-to-t3392562). With 48% remaining, I am projected to reach over 90hrs off charger with more than 5hrs of SOT.

Brightness at 40% with Auto, which is plenty bright for me indoors AND outdoors with Auto boost. Cores locked at 1Ghz (little ones) and 1.6Ghz (big ones), which is plenty of power for me. Note that Power saver mode locks them all at 1.3Ghz. I am not using the Power saver mode (extreme power save mode is different than this) because it ruins the brightness completely, and 1.3Ghz is too slow.

Nearly 4 days off charger with 5hrs SOT is totally unbelievable. This is my typical work days where I don't get to play with the phone a whole lot. HTC 10 just rocks!!

While data connectivity appears to be quite solid on this device, for someone with a lot of knowledge in how RF performance works, I can say this device could use some optimizations.  I am seeing dBm readings on both AT&T/T-Mobile bands to be 3 to 5 dBm weaker in signal throughput vs the Galaxy S7 (carrier versions).  This means at the edge of signal, the device is much more likely to drop off than to hang onto a fringe signal.

Will retest at home but the same sim in my old phone at home on my previous phone,  nexus 6P could get up to around 150mb down stream and over 45mb upstream.. Insane speeds for 4G..i haven't tested this as of yet but will do once I'm in the house,  just having a pint

Signal quality is a step down when inside compared to previous phones I've owned. This phone has a hard time holding on to weak signal, especially when inside. My Note 5 and Turbo 2 did not have problems like the HTC 10 has.

Here's my thread with my results.  Very little if not no difference to my Nexus 6p.

replies.text: I'm experiencing similar issues.  I am a speaker person.  I use the speakers on the 10 at least 2-3 times a day if not more to listen to music, phone calls, and watch youtube.  Like you, I came from moto x (pure), and I'll say this much, the volume on the moto x feels like it is 2 times louder, though the HTC 10 has slightly better sound quality.  I actually almost never blast my moto x to full volume where as with the 10, I think I'm almost always at full volume. every time i use the speakers on the phone. Where the HTC 10 shines is when you pair it with an expensive headphone.  Only on flights do I appreciate the HTC 10 more than the moto X.  The battery on the HTC 10 is also like 2x better than on the moto x.  I really wished the 10 was louder.  I'm happy with everything else the 10 has to offer, but unlike you I actually bought the 10 for its boomsound.    I still like the phone enough not to switch, but I would love this phone if the speakers were at least M9 standards.
